byline.contributor: Walt Bogdanich reported from Auburn, Ala., and Jacqueline Williams from New York. Megan Robertson contributed reporting from Auburn.
byline.original: By WALT BOGDANICH and JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

abstract: Debate over whether online fantasy sports betting constitutes illegal gambling has largely ignored industry's negative effect on gambling addicts; for such people, some of whom have lost tens of thousands of dollars online, technicalities governing what is gambling and what is not can feel meaningless; at issue is lack of protections for problem gamblers and young adults, particularly young men, who researchers say are more prone to taking risks (Series: Wired for Profit).
lead_paragraph: Compulsive gamblers say they have lost thousands after being drawn in by aggressive pitches and promises of quick payouts.

headline.main: For Addicts, Fantasy Sites Can Lead to Ruinous Path
headline.print_headline: Fantasy Sites Can Lead Addicts to a Ruinous Path

snippet: Compulsive gamblers say they have lost thousands after being drawn in by aggressive pitches and promises of quick payouts.
